body:
So I think those errors are fine as it looks like the build was successful.  However, when I tried to add onnxruntime.dll to my C# project as a reference, it said that it was not a valid COM component.  Was my build output also supposed to include other files that need to be added to my project?

Or am I supposed to use the NuGet ONNX Runtime package and then replace the onnxruntime DLL in the C# executable output directory?

onnxruntime.dll is a native dll. I would expect you need to reference the C# wrapper dll in a C# library. Building the C# solution (csharp\OnnxRuntime.CSharp.sln) should produce something like csharp\src\Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime\bin\Debug\netstandard1.1\Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.dll

Not sure if that is automatically built with the build script. If not it should be if --build_csharp is provided as a flag.

@skottmckay Thanks for the reply.

So I had run this command:
build.bat --cmake_path "C:\Program Files\CMake\bin\cmake.exe" --config RelWithDebInfo --build_shared_lib **--build_csharp** --parallel --use_cuda --cuda_version 10.2 --cuda_home "C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v10.2" --cudnn_home "C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v10.2" --use_tensorrt --tensorrt_home "C:\TensorRT\TensorRT-7.0.0.11.Windows10.x86_64.cuda-10.2.cudnn7.6\TensorRT-7.0.0.11" --use_dnnl --cmake_generator "Visual Studio 16 2019" --skip_tests

However, it seems as though a new Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.dll did not get built.
Can you build it successfully using <root dir>\csharp\OnnxRuntime.CSharp.sln?

@skottmckay 

A few things.

So I decided to try to start from a clean directory so I cloned the git repository to that directory  I ran the same build command again using Develop Command Prompt.  

I checked CMakeOutput.log and got:
`
Looking for a CSharp compiler passed with the following output:
-- The CSharp compiler identification is Microsoft unknown 9999
-- The CSharp compiler version is 3.5.0
-- Check for working C# compiler: C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio/2019/Professional/MSBuild/Current/Bin/Roslyn/csc.exe
-- Check for working C# compiler: C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio/2019/Professional/MSBuild/Current/Bin/Roslyn/csc.exe -- works
-- Configuring done
-- Generating done
-- Build files have been written to: C:/ONNXRuntime/onnxruntime/onnxruntime/build/Windows/RelWithDebInfo/CMakeFiles/CheckCSharp

Compiling the CSharp compiler identification source file "CMakeCSharpCompilerId.cs" succeeded.
Compiler: C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio/2019/Professional/MSBuild/Current/Bin/Roslyn/csc.exe 
Build flags: 
Id flags:  

The output was:
0
Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 16.5.0+d4cbfca49 for .NET Framework
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

Project "C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\RelWithDebInfo\CMakeFiles\3.16.4\CompilerIdCSharp\CompilerIdCSharp.csproj" on node 1 (default targets).
PrepareForBuild:
  Creating directory "obj\x64\Debug\".
GenerateTargetFrameworkMonikerAttribute:
Skipping target "GenerateTargetFrameworkMonikerAttribute" because all output files are up-to-date with respect to the input files.
  Using shared compilation with compiler from directory: C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Professional\MSBuild\Current\Bin\Roslyn
CopyFilesToOutputDirectory:
  Copying file from "C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\RelWithDebInfo\CMakeFiles\3.16.4\CompilerIdCSharp\obj\x64\Debug\CompilerIdCSharp.exe" to "C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\RelWithDebInfo\CMakeFiles\3.16.4\CompilerIdCSharp\CompilerIdCSharp.exe".
  CompilerIdCSharp -> C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\RelWithDebInfo\CMakeFiles\3.16.4\CompilerIdCSharp\CompilerIdCSharp.exe
  Copying file from "C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\RelWithDebInfo\CMakeFiles\3.16.4\CompilerIdCSharp\obj\x64\Debug\CompilerIdCSharp.pdb" to "C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\RelWithDebInfo\CMakeFiles\3.16.4\CompilerIdCSharp\CompilerIdCSharp.pdb".
PostBuildEvent:
  if not "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Professional\MSBuild\Current\Bin\Roslyn"=="" if exist "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Professional\MSBuild\Current\Bin\Roslyn\csc.exe" set _CSC=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Professional\MSBuild\Current\Bin\Roslyn
  if exist "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Professional\MSBuild\Current\Bin\csc.exe" set _CSC=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Professional\MSBuild\Current\Bin
  if "%_CSC%"=="" exit -1
  @echo CMAKE_CSharp_COMPILER=%_CSC%\csc.exe
  CMAKE_CSharp_COMPILER=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Professional\MSBuild\Current\Bin\Roslyn\csc.exe
Done Building Project "C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\RelWithDebInfo\CMakeFiles\3.16.4\CompilerIdCSharp\CompilerIdCSharp.csproj" (default targets).

Build succeeded.
    0 Warning(s)
    0 Error(s)

Time Elapsed 00:00:00.43

Compilation of the CSharp compiler identification source "CMakeCSharpCompilerId.cs" produced "CompilerIdCSharp.csproj"

Compilation of the CSharp compiler identification source "CMakeCSharpCompilerId.cs" produced "CompilerIdCSharp.exe"

Compilation of the CSharp compiler identification source "CMakeCSharpCompilerId.cs" produced "CompilerIdCSharp.pdb"

The CSharp compiler identification is Microsoft unknown, found in "C:/ONNXRuntime/onnxruntime/onnxruntime/build/Windows/RelWithDebInfo/CMakeFiles/3.16.4/CompilerIdCSharp/CompilerIdCSharp.exe"

Determining if the C# compiler works passed with the following output:
Change Dir: C:/ONNXRuntime/onnxruntime/onnxruntime/build/Windows/RelWithDebInfo/CMakeFiles/CMakeTmp

Run Build Command(s):C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio/2019/Professional/MSBuild/Current/Bin/MSBuild.exe cmTC_a6d41.csproj /p:Configuration=Debug /p:Platform=x64 /p:VisualStudioVersion=16.0 /v:m && Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 16.5.0+d4cbfca49 for .NET Framework

Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
`

So it appears everything is fine, but I wanted to double check the errors so I opened CMakeError.log:
`
The CSharp compiler identification could not be found in "C:/ONNXRuntime/onnxruntime/onnxruntime/build/Windows/RelWithDebInfo/CMakeFiles/3.16.4/CompilerIdCSharp/CompilerIdCSharp.csproj"
`

I'm not sure if this was just a one time error that then succeeded.

So I tried to open \csharp\OnnxRuntime.CSharp.sln and got the following error:
Detailed Information:
Unable to locate the .NET Core SDK. Check that it is installed and that the version specified in global.json (if any) matches the installed version.

I looked at my Visual Studio Installer and saw:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/80602264-e2ea6f00-89fc-11ea-9722-494582349211.png)

It looks like I have the .NET Core SDK.  Does this have to do with the error in CMakeError.log?

If the build succeeds I don't think the output in CMakeFiles\CMakeErrors.log is relevant. CMake runs lots of tests to determine what's available/configured, and some are expected to fail. The output from these ends up in that file. I see the same error about the compiler identification not being found but have no issues loading the C# solution.

I have the same VS 2019 version with similar (fewer) SDKs installed.
> dotnet --list-sdks
2.1.500 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
2.1.502 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
2.1.503 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
2.1.505 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
2.1.507 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
2.1.508 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
2.1.511 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
2.1.513 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
3.1.201 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]

We're targeting a very basic .NET version so that should be sufficient.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/979079/80658658-0deec480-8aca-11ea-8eb3-c5223e6364da.png)

When you load the solution do the dependencies get restored/resolved, including NETStandard.Library?
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/979079/80658614-e566ca80-8ac9-11ea-8a95-e45dc4164e4e.png)

So here is my VS Window:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/80665667-1dd5bc80-8a68-11ea-9a61-df259661591e.png)

I can't even get to the project properties window because the project will not load.

The error in the output window says:
C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\csharp\test\Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Tests\Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Tests.csproj : error  : The project file cannot be opened by the project system, because it is missing some critical imports or the referenced SDK cannot be found.

Detailed Information:
Unable to locate the .NET Core SDK. Check that it is installed and that the version specified in global.json (if any) matches the installed version.
Can you right-click on one of the projects in Solution Explorer and reload it to see what additional info you get in the Output window? Sometimes that can provide more useful error messages.

OK I repaired my installation using my VS Installer and the project seems to open.  However, when I try to build the "Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime" project, I get an error:
Could not copy the file "C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\Debug\Debug\onnxruntime.dll" because it was not found.

I went to "C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows" to look at the directory structure:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/80923080-3affd900-8d4f-11ea-923a-162943e80f99.png)

I don't have a "Debug" directory in that folder.

If I go into the "RelWithDebInfo" folder:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/80923105-6c78a480-8d4f-11ea-9de0-5ab4665199e0.png)

The only place in the build directory that I found an onnxruntime,dll file is in: C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\RelWithDebInfo\RelWithDebInfo

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/80924097-1dce0900-8d55-11ea-85aa-a735cab48825.png)

I then just copied that dll file into: C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\Debug\Debug

I then built "Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime" and the project built successfully.  I then saw this in the output directory:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/80924247-d72cde80-8d55-11ea-84b1-9cdb98f89d00.png)


One other important note is that one of the reasons I am building from source is that I want to experiment with TensorRT runtime optimization (which is why I put the --use_tensorrt in my build command when using developer command prompt).  If I use this generated Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.dll file, will it allow me to use TensorRT optimizations?

Here is my screenshot of the project properties:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/80924279-093e4080-8d56-11ea-80b5-332bafb762c7.png)

It looks like this should be possible?  For some reason I expected the build time to take long but it only took a few seconds.

The target is matched for all projects generated by the build, so you'd need to set the C# solution to the RelWithDebInfo configuration as that was the build config. Visual Studio tends to default to the Debug config. 

Alternatively you could try pointing it to the onnxruntime.dll in build\Windows\RelWithDebInfo\RelWithDebInfo. It should work but isn't tested.
@skottmckay Thanks for the reply.  Forgive me for asking, but how do I set the C# solution to RelWithDebInfo config?  Would I add the RelWithDebInfo in the conditional compilation symbols?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/979079/80930278-ed8a7700-8df5-11ea-9209-2d4015b9bf1e.png)

Select the configuration from the dropdown menu in VS.

@skottmckay Thanks for the clear instruction.  What's interesting is that when I do that, I get the error:

Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Error	MSB3030	Could not copy the file "C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\Release\Release\onnxruntime.dll" because it was not found.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/81123114-52ca8f00-8f00-11ea-93c5-46bc31240f25.png)


Basically it's looking in the "Release" folder instead of the "RelWithDebInfo" folder.

So alternatively I went back to Debug and moved the onnxruntime.dll file into C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\build\Windows\Debug\Debug.  This generated an Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.dll file.  

I tried to use this file in my project, by right clicking add references and then add this DLL.  Unfortunately I got a runtime error:
System.TypeInitializationException: 'The type initializer for 'Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.NativeMethods' threw an exception.'
DllNotFoundException: Unable to load DLL 'onnxruntime': The specified module could not be found. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x8007007E)

Now this seems like a simple error -- just put the onnxruntime.dll file inside the same folder as the exe.  I did that but this error is still there.

I also have another project with the exact same code, except in that project I use the NuGet package and that works fine.  So it seems the error is related to my generated Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.dll

The C# projects needed a RelWithDebInfo configuration defined. There's a PR to address this.

Most likely it's a dependency that's missing. I would expect you need to copy dnnl.dll as well, and the CUDA dlls would need to be in the PATH of the environment Visual Studio is started in for them to be found as well.
Do the exception details say what the error was?

Looks like the error code is: -2147467259

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/82612359-b1466d00-9b90-11ea-9941-8c2a45571783.png)

Unfortunately not too many other details.  What could the cause be?  Could it be due to a missing DLL or a bad build?

Actually it looks like I may have had to put one or more of the following files in the Debug directory as well:
- myelin64_1.dll
- nvparsers.dll
- nvserialize.dll
- nvonnxparser.dll

I then got this message: [W:onnxruntime:CSharpOnnxRuntime, tensorrt_execution_provider.h:36 onnxruntime::TensorrtLogger::log] [2020-05-21 22:49:33 WARNING] C:\ONNXRuntime\onnxruntime\onnxruntime\cmake\external\onnx-tensorrt\onnx2trt_utils.cpp:235: Your ONNX model has been generated with INT64 weights, while TensorRT does not natively support INT64. Attempting to cast down to INT32.

What can I do to prevent this cast down?  It seems to have quite a bit of overhead.  It seems that when I load without TensorRT this does not occur.

In fact what I am noticing is the following:
- Going through the using statement takes a significant amount of time 
- Performing the first inference takes a significant amount of time (maybe ~25X slower than not using TensorRT)
- Then each subsequent pass through the network has a 25% reduction in latency as compared to not using TensorRT

Now if I could fix the first inference and setup issues this would be great.
Actually seems like I am delving into another issue, as the build process itself seems fine now.  Thanks for the help @skottmckay !

fail build with the latest Master. Anyone has similar problem?

`build.bat --cmake_path "C:\Program Files\CMake\bin\cmake.exe" --config RelWithDebInfo --build_shared_lib --build_csharp --parallel --use_cuda --cuda_version 10.2 --cuda_home "C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v10.2" --cudnn_home "C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v10.2" --use_tensorrt --tensorrt_home "C:\TensorRT\TensorRT-7.0.0.11.Windows10.x86_64.cuda-10.2.cudnn7.6\TensorRT-7.0.0.11" --use_dnnl --cmake_generator "Visual Studio 16 2019" --skip_tests`
